user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GetResourceName:
```c
int32 OS_GetResourceName(osal_id_t object_id, char *buffer, size_t buffer_size)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    size_t              name_len;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* sanity check the passed-in buffer and size */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(buffer_size);

    /*
     * Initially set the output string to empty.
     * This avoids undefined behavior in case the function fails
     * and the caller does not check the return code.
     */
    buffer[0] = 0;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(object_id), object_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(&token);

        if (record->name_entry != NULL)
        {
            name_len = OS_strnlen(record->name_entry, buffer_size);
            if (buffer_size <= name_len)
            {
                /* indicates the name does not fit into supplied buffer */
                return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG;
                name_len    = buffer_size - 1;
            }
            memcpy(buffer, record->name_entry, name_len);
            buffer[name_len] = 0;
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GetResourceName:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
static inline osal_objtype_t OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(osal_id_t id)
{
    return (OS_ObjectIdToInteger(id) >> OS_OBJECT_TYPE_SHIFT);
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
OS_common_record_t *OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    uint32 base_idx = OS_GetBaseForObjectType(token->obj_type);
    return &OS_common_table[base_idx + token->obj_idx];
}
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
static inline size_t OS_strnlen(const char *s, size_t maxlen)
{
    const char *end = (const char *)memchr(s, 0, maxlen);
    if (end != NULL)
    {
        /* actual length of string is difference */
        maxlen = end - s;
    }
    return maxlen;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG (-13)
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Fragments not listed were omitted because they are clearly necessary for observable program behaviour or are simple declarations/returns that cannot be dead code on their own. Specifically:
- Declarations (int32 return_code; size_t name_len; OS_common_record_t *record; OS_object_token_t token;) are not executable operations and thus are not candidates for dead code.
- The outer if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS) and the check if (record->name_entry != NULL) control whether the operations execute; they are essential control-flow elements and not themselves dead.
- The call to OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(...) and use of the returned record pointer are included above where relevant; other internal helper functions (OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl, OS_ObjectIdGetById and its transaction logic) perform side effects (object lookup, locking) so their invocation is necessary and cannot be assumed dead without system-wide analysis — only the specific call sites listed above are flagged for further review.
- The final return return_code; is the function result and cannot be removed without changing behaviour.

The fragments listed should be investigated because they are executable operations that might be redundant in some configurations or workloads (for example: initialization that is always overwritten, checks/macros that may be no-ops in some builds, copies/terminations that may always be overridden, or release calls that may be unnecessary depending on how tokens/locks are managed). Other code in the function either provides necessary control flow or performs side effects that make them unlikely to be dead code, so they were not flagged.
